column5: any help is appreciated...    you cant see in the pic too well but the fins are very sharp and also running a good distance down the back
Probably some kind of Stickleback, would help to see the dorsal fin erect.
looks like a minnow in someones hand

my thoughts as well. i could get a better pic as i was alone. dorsal fin was sharp and boney and ran maybe 3/5ths the length. if you look closely you can see minute humps on the back.  i tried to adjust the exposure for a better view but for some reason it wont save. ill keep trying. never seen these in the RR before
Yup, I'd say stickle-back as well. Neat little buggers.
http://www.dfo-mpo.gc.ca/Library/349568.pdf  This is a pretty good reference to Ontario Baitfish.
thanks dave that was the link i was looking for before i posted. still cant find it on there though? it had one long boney/sharp dorsal fin run its back. no individual spike.
looks like a brook stickleback to me but no way to identify for sure without counting the spines
Atlantic.
Most definitely a Brook Stickleback, if you look close you can see the spines
Live Target Stickleback?
never gets old eh bill? hahahahaha.  LOL!!!  I can't help it
never seen one before, now walleye are full of em. might have migrated down from LOTW during the flood waters?

stickle back, not the common 3 spine though  I have a book, Freshwater Fishes of Canada, Scott and Crossman, as a fisherperson or outdoors person, it's a great reference  if a used copy is online and cheap, it's facinating and great to have
Agreed I have the same book... Got it as a Christmas gift. Awesome resource
Stickle back
Saweeeeet! What kind of braid shall i use to catch these beauties? Hahaha
Saweeeeet! What kind of braid shall i use to catch these beauties? Hahaha   All braid is the same, make sure you use wire though.
Apparently you need marshmallows???
I'm going to guess Nine-spine Stickleback. Would be best to see a photo with the spines showing but the caudal peduncle looks to be too long to be a Brook Stickleback.  Jon
